unnormalised: Navigating the labyrinthine world of Indian addresses is an adventure in itself, especially when you’re trying to book a hotel. Forget GPS; you’ll need a seasoned chai-wallah and a carrier pigeon to decipher some of these postal enigmas. I swear, some addresses read like cryptic crossword clues devised by a committee of mischievous gnomes. My last trip to Jaipur nearly ended with me camping in a cow shed because “Opp. Hawa Mahal” could mean anything from a royal view to a bovine rendezvous.

Forget G-P-S; you’ll need a seasoned chai-wallah and a carrier pigeon to decipher some of these postal enigmas. My last trip to Jaipur nearly ended with me camping in a cow shed because “Opposite Hawa Mahal” could mean anything from a royal view to a bovine rendezvous.

unnormalised: Take, for example, my quest to find “Hotel Maharaja Palace, Near Railway Station, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302006”. Sounds simple enough, right? Wrong. The “near” in Indian addresses is a relative term, like saying Pluto is “near” the Earth. After driving in circles for what felt like 3 hours (probably closer to 45 minutes, but who’s counting when you're battling auto-rickshaws?), I finally found it tucked away behind a bustling market selling everything from bangles to live chickens. Turns out, “near” meant “within a 5km radius, good luck finding it.”

The “near” in Indian addresses is a relative term, like saying Pluto is “near” the Earth. After driving in circles for what felt like three hours (probably closer to forty five minutes, but who’s counting when you're battling auto-rickshaws?), I finally found it tucked away behind a bustling market selling everything from bangles to live chickens. Turns out, “near” meant “within a five kilometer radius, good luck finding it.”

unnormalised: Then there was the time I tried booking a place in Goa. The address was something along the lines of “House No. 7/B, Anjuna, Bardez, Goa, 403509”. Seven slash B! Is that even a real thing? Did they run out of numbers and start improvising? I envisioned a tiny hobbit hole nestled between house number seven and house number eight, accessible only by crawling on my hands and knees. Turns out, it was a charming little guesthouse, but the journey there felt like an Indiana Jones adventure.

unnormalised: Don't even get me started on the use of landmarks. "Behind the Big Hanuman Temple, Delhi, 110001" – great, which Big Hanuman Temple? Delhi probably has more Big Hanuman Temples than it has people willing to queue for pani puri. You end up relying on the kindness of strangers, who, bless their hearts, often provide directions that are more confusing than helpful. "Go straight, then take a left at the third gali, ask for Sharmaji ka beta, he'll know." Sharmaji ka beta could be anyone from a rickshaw driver to the local MLA.

unnormalised: And the postal codes! They're like lottery numbers, utterly random and baffling. Trying to remember if it’s 400001 or 400011 or some other permutation of zeros and ones is a cognitive challenge on par with solving a Rubik's Cube while balancing on a unicycle. You’d think in the age of GPS, we'd have moved past this madness, but no. Indian addresses remain a testament to the country's beautiful, chaotic, and wonderfully illogical charm.

unnormalised: So, the next time you’re booking a hotel in India and encounter an address that makes you question the very fabric of reality, remember this: embrace the adventure. Pack your patience, your sense of humor, and maybe a GPS-enabled homing pigeon. You're going to need them. And for heaven's sake, learn to decipher "Opposite." It might just save you from a night spent cuddling cows.
